result.execSummary:
On one or more charges in this case, Nathan D. Weingandt was found not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect. The defendant was found guilty of actually committing the crime(s) charged, but was also found not to be legally responsible under Wis. Stats. 971.165 for committing the crime(s) because of the defendant's mental condition. The legal effect of a finding of not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect is that the court must commit the defendant to the custody of the Department of Health and Family Services.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

Defendant Nathan D. Weingandt in court via video from Winnebago with attorney Rebecca Hammock.  Matthew R. Leusink appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Order for supplemental exam. Minutes filed.  Review hearing scheduled for August 3, 2015 at 11:00 am.
Defendant Nathan D. Weingandt in court with attorney Rebecca Hammock.  Matthew R. Leusink appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Minutes filed.  Review scheduled for July 7, 2015 at 11:00 am.

Defendant Nathan D. Weingandt in court, in custody with attorney Rebecca Hammock.  Matthew R. Leusink appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Court makes a finding of guilt, but not guilty by reason  of mental disease/defect. Minutes filed.  Hearing scheduled for May 19, 2015 at 08:15 am.

Defendant Nathan D. Weingandt in court, in custody with attorney Rebecca Hammock.  Matthew R. Leusink appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Minutes filed.  Bond remains.  Plea/sentencing hearing scheduled for March 26, 2015 at 08:15 am.
Signed bond filed with the court.
COURT ORDERS NO VIOLENT CONTACT WITH ANY EMPLOYEE OF DHS.  "No violent contact" includes threats through the mail, by telephone, by way of electronic device, in person or through a third party.

Defendant Nathan D. Weingandt in court in custody with attorney Julia May for Rebecca Hammock.  Tracy L. McMiller appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Court orders NGI exam. Bond remains.  Minutes filed.  Status conference scheduled for March 23, 2015 at 08:15 am.
Plaintiff's Demand and Motion for Discovery and Inspection.  Notice of Motion and Motion for Establishment of Discovery Deadlines.
Signed bond filed with the court.

*AMENDMENT 2-23-2015 - COURT ORDERS NO VIOLENT CONTACT WITH ANY EMPLOYEE OF DHS.  "No violent contact" includes threats through the mail, by telephone, by way of electronic device, in person or through a third party.

Defendant will not in any way contact or attempt to contact any victim(s) listed and will avoid their residence/place of employment or any place they are located and will avoid causing any other person, other than defendant's attorney, from doing so on defendant's behalf.  The term "no contact" is hereby defined as through the mail, by telephone, by way of electronic device, in person, or through a third party.  VICTIM(S)/RESIDENCE(S): NO CONTACT WITH C.S. Defendant shall personally ensure that payments are made under any Order for Income Withholding if the Court appoints an attorney for the defendant.
Defendant in court in custody with attorney Rebecca Hammock. Valerian Powell appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Minutes filed.
